00006 #ifndef _LIGHTTPD_PLUGIN_HPP_
00007 #define _LIGHTTPD_PLUGIN_HPP_
00008 
00009 #include <cstddef>
00010 
00011 #include "c++-compat/plugin.h"
00012 
00013 #include "handler_helpers.hpp"
00014 #include "datatype_helpers.hpp"
00015 
00051 class plugin_base
00052 {
00053 protected:
00054         // We always have a reference to the C plugin structure
00055         // lighty handles the freeing of p
00056         plugin_base( const char* name, const std::size_t version, plugin& p )
00057          : p( p ), srv( 0 ) // don't know srv yet, need initialize
00058         {
00059                 p.name = buffer_init_string( name );
00060                 p.version = version;
00061                 p.data = reinterpret_cast< void* >( this );
00062 
00063                 // We don't have enough infomation to call init.
00064                 // Instead, call it from set_defaults_wrapper
00065 
00066                 // p.init = &plugin_base::initialize_wrapper;
00067                 p.set_defaults = &plugin_base::set_defaults_wrapper;
00068         }
00069 
00070         plugin& p;
00071         const server* srv;
00072 
00073 public:
00074 
00075         // Here we have functions that are required by (almost) all plugins
00076 
00077         // For set defaults, we just call set defaults on all config_options
00078         // in the current translation unit.
00079         handler_t set_defaults( )
00080         {
00081                 return config_option_base::set_all_defaults( );
00082         }
00083 
00084         static handler_t set_defaults_wrapper( server* s, void* p_d )
00085         {
00086                 plugin_base& p = reinterpret_cast< plugin_base& >( p_d );
00087                 initialize_wrapper( s, p_d );
00088                 return p.set_defaults( );
00089         }
00090 
00091         // Set srv and return this.  There are quite a few inconsistencies here I know,
00092         // this should really be called directly and return a newly allocated plugin.
00093         // Its a tug of war between C and C++ ways.  I choose to init the plugin in
00094         // create_plugin and set p->data in the plugin_base constructor.
00095         void* initialize( const server& s )
00096         {
00097                 srv = &s;
00098                 return reinterpret_cast< void* >( this );
00099         }
00100 
00101         static void* initialize_wrapper( server* s, void* p_d )
00102         {
00103                 plugin_base& p = reinterpret_cast< plugin_base& >( p_d );
00104                 return p.initialize( *s );
00105         }
00106 };
00107 
00113 template< typename MostDerived >
00114 class Plugin : public plugin_base
00115 {
00116         typedef plugin_base super_type;
00117 
00118 protected:
00119         // Private constructor for setting plugin name.
00120         // Could say this is a part of the traditional lighty init function
00121         Plugin( const char* name, const std::size_t version, plugin& p )
00122          : plugin_base( name, version, p )
00123         {
00124                 // The handler setter to use to configure hooks in plugin p below.
00125                 typedef typename handlers_setter< MostDerived >::type setter;
00126 
00127                 // use for_each to set the appropriate function pointers
00128                 // in the plugin structure, dependend on the type "handlers"
00129                 // defined in a derived class.
00130                 setter::set( p );
00131         }
00132 
00133 public:
00134         // This is to be called after entry, i.e. from _plugin_init.
00135         // We can't really eliminate the need to implement _plugin_init in
00136         // derived modules as we have to have the correct function name.
00137         // use the DEFINE_MODULE macro to create the appropriate entry function.
00138         static int create_plugin( plugin& p )
00139         {
00140                 // Make sure exceptions do not propergate to C code
00141                 try
00142                 {
00143                         new MostDerived( p );
00144                         return 0;
00145                 }
00146                 catch( ... )
00147                 {
00148                         return 1;
00149                 }
00150         }
00151 };
00152 
00153 // A list of defined interfaces.
00154 // The first argument specifies a typedef handle to the handler types,
00155 // the second specifies the handle name as seen in the plugin structure.
00156 // This macro is only for handlers that take just the connection.
00157 MAKE_HANDLER( UriRawHandler,       handle_uri_raw       );
00158 MAKE_HANDLER( UriCleanHandler,     handle_uri_clean     );
00159 MAKE_HANDLER( DocRootHandler,      handle_docroot       );
00160 MAKE_HANDLER( PhysicalHandler,     handle_physical      );
00161 MAKE_HANDLER( StartBackendHandler, handle_start_backend );
00162 
00163 // This is defined in handler_helpers.hpp .  It should not be used by derived plugins.
00164 #undef MAKE_HANDLER
00165 
00166 // Given your plugin name, this will create the entry point for lighttpd to use.
00167 // To be used in your plugins cpp file.
00168 #define MAKE_PLUGIN( name ) \
00169         extern "C" \
00170         { \
00171                 static int name##_plugin_init( plugin* p ) \
00172                 { \
00173                         return Plugin< name >::create_plugin( *p ); \
00174                 } \
00175         }
00176 
00177 #endif // _LIGHTTPD_PLUGIN_HPP_
